messages.content:
It is not possible to implement an LRU cache in Swift. LRU stands for "Least recently used" and is a makeshift solution to the problem of memory management in computer programs. In an LRU cache, the most recently used items are removed from the cache first in order to make room for new items.

In Swift, memory management is implemented using reference counting, which tracks the number of references to each object in memory. This allows the Swift runtime to determine when an object is no longer needed and free up its memory. It is not possible to implement an LRU cache using reference counting, as removing an object from the cache would require changing the reference count of other objects in memory, which could result in unpredictable behavior.

It is recommended to use a standard memory management library, such as Foundation or Collection, instead of implementing your own LRU cache in Swift. These libraries provide built-in functionality for managing memory, such as removing items from a cache based on their age or usage frequency, and can be easily integrated into your Swift code.
